title: A semi-Lagrangian $\epsilon$-monotone Fourier method for continuous withdrawal GMWBs under jump-diffusion with stochastic interest rate. (arXiv:2310.00606v1 [q-fin.CP])
abstract: We develop an efficient pricing approach for guaranteed minimum withdrawal benefits (GMWBs) with continuous withdrawals under a realistic modeling setting with jump-diffusions and stochastic interest rate. Utilizing an impulse stochastic control framework, we formulate the no-arbitrage GMWB pricing problem as a time-dependent Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman (HJB) Quasi-Variational Inequality (QVI) having three spatial dimensions with cross derivative terms. Through a novel numerical approach built upon a combination of a semi-Lagrangian method and the Green's function of an associated linear partial integro-differential equation, we develop an $\epsilon$-monotone Fourier pricing method, where $\epsilon > 0$ is a monotonicity tolerance. translated_title: 半拉格朗日 $\epsilon$-单调性傅里叶方法用于具有随机利率的跳跃扩散下的连续提款GMWBs定价
translated_abstract: 我们在一个跳跃扩散和随机利率的现实建模环境下，为具有连续提款的保证最小提款收益（GMWBs）开发了一种高效的定价方法。利用冲击随机控制框架，我们将无套利GMWB定价问题形式化为一个时间依赖的Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman（HJB）准变分不等式（QVI），其中拥有三个空间维度和交叉导数项。通过一种新颖的数值方法，将半拉格朗日方法与相关线性偏积分-微分方程的格林函数相结合，我们开发了一种 $\epsilon$-单调性傅里叶定价方法，其中 $\epsilon > 0$ 是一个单调性容许度。结合HJB-QVI的可证强比较结果，我们在数学上证明了所提出的方案收敛到HJB-QVI的粘性解，当 $\epsilon \to 0$ 时。我们对同时连续提款和投资风险的影响进行了全面研究。
tldr: 本文提供了一个半拉格朗日 $\epsilon$-单调性傅里叶方法，用于跳跃扩散和随机利率下的连续提款GMWBs的定价问题。通过结合半拉格朗日方法和相关线性偏积分-微分方程的格林函数，我们建立了一个 $\epsilon$-单调性傅里叶定价方法。通过数学证明，我们展示了该方法收敛到HJB-QVI的粘性解，同时综合研究了连续提款和投资风险的影响。
en_tdlr: This paper presents a semi-Lagrangian $\epsilon$-monotone Fourier method for pricing continuous withdrawal guaranteed minimum withdrawal benefits (GMWBs) under jump-diffusion with stochastic interest rate. The proposed method combines semi-Lagrangian approach and the Green's function of an associated linear partial integro-differential equation, and mathematically demonstrates convergence to the viscosity solution of the HJB-QVI. The paper also conducts a comprehensive study on the impact of continuous withdrawals and investment risk.
